author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Hungary Inspires So Much Fear and Fascination
description: Liberals and conservatives see America when they look at Budapest.
content: For the last few years, Hungary, a country of fewer than 10 million people, has occupied an outsize place in the imagination of American liberals and conservatives. If you think the American right is sliding toward authoritarianism, you cite Viktor Orban’s nationalist government as a dark model for the G.O.P. If you think an intolerant progressivism shadows American life, you invoke Orban as a figure who’s fighting back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump’s Repeating Donation Tactics Led to Millions in Refunds Into 2021
description: Donald Trump and the Republican Party returned $12.8 million to donors in the first half of the year, a sign that their aggressive fund-raising tactics ensnared many unwitting contributors.
content: The aggressive fund-raising tactics that former President Donald J. Trump deployed late in last year’s presidential campaign have continued to spur an avalanche of refunds into 2021, with Mr. Trump, the Republican Party and their shared accounts returning $12.8 million to donors in the first six months of the year, newly released federal records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Quislings of Albany
description: Cuomo, time's up.
content: WASHINGTON — “Pamela; or Virtue Rewarded” by Samuel Richardson is an 18th-century British novel about a powerful man who makes life a horror for a pretty young maidservant by constantly harassing and assaulting her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Video of Officer’s Collapse After Handling Powder Draws Skepticism
description: Medical experts said the video promoted a false narrative and confusion about fentanyl and ways it can lead to an overdose.
content: A dramatic video posted by the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department that shows a trainee collapsing while investigating a substance he believed to be fentanyl has been met with skepticism from medical and addiction experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Tomato Time!
description: Whether you toss them with chickpeas, feta and a beautifully crunchy topping, or grate them for paneer con tomate, these recipes will put them to good use.
content: Tejal here, filling in for Emily. I’m writing to you from my galley kitchen in Los Angeles, just back from a week of vacation where I didn’t go anywhere. I read a lot near the air-conditioner, cooked when it cooled down in the evenings, and spent longer than usual at the park with my dogs. I mean, sure, it would have been nice to drink frozen margaritas on a beach with my friends, but this isn’t a complaint — I love being home with time off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fahim Abed and Sharif Hassan
title: Taliban Take Second Afghan City in Two Days
description: Sheberghan, in Jowzjan Province, collapsed less than 24 hours after a provincial capital in southwestern Afghanistan had fallen to the Taliban.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Another provincial capital, the second in two days, all but fell on Saturday in Afghanistan, officials said, this one in the country’s north, where a Taliban offensive has surrounded several cities since international forces began withdrawing in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Brazil beats Spain in extra time to repeat as the Olympic men’s soccer champion.
description: The Olympic men’s tournament is an under-23 championship, but it remains an important barometer of a country’s ability to produce young talent.
content: It took Brazil 64 years to win its first Olympic gold medal in soccer. Five years later, it has its second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What to Watch at the Closing Ceremony of the Tokyo Games
description: There will be music and speeches, and a handoff to Paris for the 2024 Games.
content: The details of the Tokyo Olympics closing ceremony are closely guarded before it begins. And the coronavirus pandemic has changed a lot. But based on the closing ceremonies of the recent past, we can still safely predict some of what we’ll see starting at 8 p.m. Tokyo time on Sunday night (7 a.m. Eastern).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Emily Cochrane
title: For G.O.P., Infrastructure Bill Is a Chance to Inch Away From Trump
description: The former president’s efforts to bring down the bipartisan deal fell mostly on deaf ears among Republicans, signaling his waning influence on Capitol Hill. Can it last?
content: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump tried mightily to kill the $1 trillion infrastructure bill, hurling the kind of insult-laden statements and threats of primary challenges that for years sent a chill down Republican spines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Paris 2024 Presses On With Plan A, but Studies Tokyo’s Plan B
description: The next Summer Olympics are less than three years away. Paris says it’s prepared, but so was Tokyo.
content: TOKYO — Tony Estanguet wants to talk about how the next Olympic Games, in Paris in 2024, will be a paradigm-shifting moment for an event that has come under fire for becoming too bloated, too costly, too onerous for the citizens of the places where the quadrennial sporting jamboree lands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: They Don’t Want the Shot. They Don’t Want Colleagues to Know.
description: Nearly 40 percent of Americans over the age of 18 remain unvaccinated, and could return to their offices with policies in place that make that status clear.
content: Vincent Taranto has felt like less of a pariah at work in the last few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Novak and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Conservative Fellow Travelers: Tucker Carlson Drops In On Viktor Orban
description: This week, the talk show host has been in Hungary, where Prime Minister Viktor Orban hopes to set up an ideological center for a global conservative movement.
content: BUDAPEST — It’s been a meeting of conservative fellow travelers: a jovial host — who heads an authoritarian government bent on targeting liberal institutions, including universities, the judiciary and the media — and his American guest exchanging grins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Here’s how to watch the game in the United States.
description: The game will be on NBC in the United States at 10:30 p.m. Eastern time.
content: The United States and France play at Saitama Super Arena at 11:30 a.m. Saturday in Tokyo, which is 13 hours ahead of Eastern time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: U.S. women’s water polo wins its third straight gold medal.
description: One of the most dominant teams of recent Olympics routed Spain, 14-5, led by three goals from Maddie Musselman.
content: TOKYO — The U.S. women’s water polo team won its third consecutive Olympic gold medal on Saturday, routing Spain, 14-5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Glenn Thrush, Charlie Savage and Alan Rappeport
title: As Democrats Seethed, White House Struggled to Contain Eviction Fallout
description: The president was surprised by the reaction to the White House’s decision to ask Congress to extend an eviction ban, leading to a 36-hour scramble to keep people in their homes.
content: WASHINGTON — By the time President Biden returned from his weekend retreat at Camp David on Monday, his White House was engulfed in a political crisis as thousands of families faced the risk of eviction in the middle of a resurgent pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: From Athens to Tokyo, Allyson Felix’s Journey to the Olympic Record Books
description: Felix’s 11th medal made her the most decorated American track-and-field athlete in Olympic history, surpassing Carl Lewis.
content: TOKYO — Allyson Felix had made her mark, collecting so many titles and winning so many races as the most celebrated female athlete in American track and field. By Saturday night, her accomplishments were officially unparalleled in U.S. track, and she found herself in a familiar position at Olympic Stadium: atop the podium with a gold medal draped around her neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Nelly Korda of the U.S. captures the gold in women’s golf.
description: Her victory, six days after Xander Schauffele won the gold in men’s golf, gave the United States a sweep of the tournaments at the Tokyo Olympics.
content: Nelly Korda of the United States held off a final-round challenge from Japan’s Mone Inami and New Zealand’s Lydia Ko to claim the gold medal in women’s golf at Kasumigaseki Country Club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greek Fires Force Thousands More to Evacuate
description: Wildfires are raging in Greece and Turkey as southern Europe faces one of its worst heat waves in decades.
content: ATHENS — Firefighters continued to battle blazes across Greece on Saturday after another difficult night that saw thousands more people fleeing their homes and hundreds being evacuated by sea, as southern Europe grapples with one of its worst heat waves in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: On the final day of the Tokyo Games, gold medal matches and the men’s marathon.
description: The United States has caught up to China in the gold medal race.
content: TOKYO — The final day of the Tokyo Olympics began early, with the men’s marathon at 7 a.m. on Sunday, Tokyo time (Saturday at 6 p.m. Eastern time). The race was held in the northern city of Sapporo in an effort to avoid the worst of Tokyo’s summer heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Fragrance Maker Dares to Sniff ‘What Life Really Smells Like’
description: Crafting scents that demand a brave nose, and leading smelling tours through a landscape in Catalonia painted by Dalí, an evangelist of odor urges people to catch a whiff of the “sublime.”
content: CAP DE CREUS, Spain — Of all those wishing a swift end to the pandemic, few have reasons as obsessed with the olfactory as Ernesto Collado, an actor turned fragrance maker whose workshop sits in a village in the northeast corner of Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell and Priya Krishna
title: Back to Normal? It’s a Tall Order as New York City Restaurants Struggle.
description: Diners are flocking back this summer, but owners still have trouble hiring, stocking kitchens and paying rent. And an uncertain autumn looms.
content: At Sylvia’s Restaurant, a 59-year-old Harlem mainstay that rode out the shocks and shutdowns of the pandemic’s first year, the city’s return to full-capacity indoor dining this spring and summer has simply brought a new set of challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan, Edgar Sandoval, Adria Malcolm and Christopher Lee
title: How a Holy Mountain Became a Migration Path to the U.S.
description: Desperate migrants are scaling Mount Cristo Rey, an icon of the Southwest. A threefold increase in border crossings near El Paso is due in part to a pandemic health order that has resulted in a contest of wills.
content: SUNLAND PARK, N.M. — Towering over the borderland, Mount Cristo Rey is nature’s barrier between Mexico and the United States. Each year for nearly a century it has drawn thousands of people who tread up a constellation of switchbacks representing the “Via Crucis,” or Way of the Cross, to pray beneath the 29-foot-tall limestone crucifix at the summit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Nach Waxman, Founder of a Bookstore Where Foodies Flock, Dies at 84
description: A “kitchen anthropologist,” he created a mecca in Manhattan for chefs, writers, scholars, everyday cooks and anyone else who is, well, hungry for culinary knowledge.
content: Nach Waxman, who combined his seasoning in anthropology and nonfiction editing to found a Manhattan bookstore that became a global mecca for chefs, cooks, culinary academics, epicurean writers and just about anyone who enjoyed eating as much as he did, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Jon Lindbergh, Aviator’s Son Who Took to the Sea, Dies at 88
description: Family triumph (Charles Lindbergh’s trans-Atlantic flight) and tragedy (the kidnapping “crime of the century”) shaped his early life, but he made his mark in the depths.
content: Jon Lindbergh, an acclaimed deep-sea diver and underwater demolition expert whose life as the son of Col. Charles A. Lindbergh was shaped by the height of fame and the depths of tragedy that his family experienced, died on July 29 at his home in Lewisburg, W.Va. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: They Used the Bible to Attack Her. She Used the Bible to Forgive Them.
description: A Florida city considers apologizing to the trans city council woman they forced out a decade ago.
content: In June, the city of Largo, Fla., celebrated Pride Month. A rainbow flag flew over City Hall; at a meeting of the city commission, a speaker noted that the city’s success was attributable in part to its diversity. A proclamation issued by the city noted that one reason to observe Pride Month was to “acknowledge the history of prejudice and discrimination toward lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and nonbinary individuals.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola and Matt Futterman
title: Allyson Felix wins her 11th Olympic medal, surpassing Carl Lewis’s American record.
description: She is now the most decorated American Olympian in track and field after she and the U.S. team won the women’s 4x400-meter relay.
content: TOKYO — Allyson Felix has won her 11th Olympic medal, making her the most decorated American Olympian in track and field, surpassing the 10 medals won by Carl Lewis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Behind the Haiti Assassination, Colombia’s Growing Mercenary Industry
description: Exporting soldiers has become a vast industry in Colombia, fueled by the country’s long U.S.-backed war, limited opportunity at home and growing demand abroad.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — In Haiti, investigators continue to search for the mastermind behind the hiring of more than 20 former Colombian soldiers for a mission that ended in the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse, plunging the already troubled island nation into crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: They Wait Hours to Withdraw Cash, but Most A.T.M.s Are Empty
description: Myanmar has been crippled by a cash shortage since the military seized power six months ago, plunging the Southeast Asian nation into a financial crisis.
content: The customers, desperate for cash, began lining up at the A.T.M. at 3:30 a.m. By dawn, the queue had swelled to more than 300 people. By noon, when temperatures had reached 100 degrees, many were still waiting, hoping this would be the day they could finally withdraw money from their own bank accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Former Acting Attorney General Testifies About Trump’s Efforts to Subvert Election
description: The testimony highlights the former president’s desire to batter the Justice Department into advancing his personal agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — Jeffrey A. Rosen, who was acting attorney general during the Trump administration, has told the Justice Department watchdog and congressional investigators that one of his deputies tried to help former President Donald J. Trump subvert the results of the 2020 election, according to a person familiar with the interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Sifan Hassan Establishes Her Dominance in Tokyo
description: Hassan won Olympic medals in three grueling events: the 1,500, the 5,000 and the 10,000 meters.
content: TOKYO — At the end of 24,500 meters of hard running in six races over nine days, Sifan Hassan of the Netherlands stood alone before tumbling to the track, disbelief etched across her face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Bit of Deception
description: With Adam Aaronson as chief mixologist, you can be sure of only one thing: Surprises are in store.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I had a tough time finding a way into Adam Aaronson’s benignly fiendish Saturday puzzle. Some constructors, and Mr. Aaronson seems to be one of them, excel at writing clues that have the precision necessary for the right answer to click smartly into place when it is entered, yet are just vague enough to have seven or 12 or 29 of those potential right answers. Frustrating? Yup. Fun? Totally. Slow? Exceptionally, but maybe that’s just me. Rewarding? Very much so. As I filled in and deleted and filled in and deleted (happily, I wasn’t tethered to a pen or pencil) some almost-poetic patterns revealed themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Thomas
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Saturday night includes women’s basketball, boxing and water polo.
description: The American boxers Keyshawn Davis and Richard Torrez Jr. have gold medal bouts.
content: Here are some highlights of the U.S. broadcast schedule on Saturday evening and overnight. All times are Eastern and subject to network changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Gareth Hughes, Sports Producer With a Human Touch, Dies at 41
description: A multiple Emmy winner, he created a specialty in crafting “teases,” short videos that precede major events like the Masters and N.F.L. playoff games.
content: Gareth Hughes, an Emmy Award-winning producer at CBS Sports who specialized in crafting the short cinematic introductions that precede major broadcasts, died on July 30 in Manhattan. He was 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can the Seller of My House Promise the Furniture to Someone Else?
description: Some people welcome new neighbors with a basket of cookies or a potted plant. Others do it with a demand to take your stuff.
content: Q: My partner just purchased her first home with money from a surprise inheritance. To our delight, the seller left a nice set of patio furniture. But when we met our new neighbor, rather than introduce herself, she told us that the seller had promised the furniture to her. This was the first we’d heard of the agreement. We don’t want to burn bridges before we even unpack, but the patio furniture is technically ours, and given our budget, we wouldn’t be able to replace it for some time. Are we being selfish by keeping it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Berkshire Hathaway Shakes Off the Ill Effects of the Pandemic
description: Its second-quarter earnings rose substantially from 2020, with its railroad, utility and energy businesses showing the biggest gains.
content: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett, substantially recovered from the ill economic effects of the pandemic in the second quarter, reporting on Saturday that it had $28.1 billion in net earnings, up from $26.3 billion a year earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Jessica Springsteen wins a silver medal with the U.S. show jumping team.
description: The daughter of Bruce Springsteen is now an Olympic medalist.
content: TOKYO — For all the accolades he has won over the years, an Olympic medal has always eluded Bruce Springsteen. Perhaps that’s because rocking out still isn’t an Olympic event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: ‘Ugh’: Life at Andrew Cuomo’s Hometown Newspaper
description: The Times Union’s strait-laced, minimal-schmooze, no off-the-record principles put it on a collision course with the notoriously press-controlling governor of New York.
content: Casey Seiler, editor in chief of The Albany Times Union, was in a meeting on Tuesday afternoon with the newspaper’s executive committee in their office near the airport when he saw a comment he made privately months earlier was now circulating on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annalee Newitz
title: From ‘Loki’ to ‘Brooklyn Nine-Nine,’ Fans Are Calling the Shots
description: Pop culture will never be the same, but maybe that’s a good thing.
content: If you’re looking forward to watching the final season of “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” when it premieres on Aug. 12, you have online fandom to thank. The popular television comedy about a snarky but lovable squad of Brooklyn cops was canceled by Fox in 2018, then picked up by NBC in less than two days, thanks to a massive outpouring of love from the show’s fans on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: Giraffes May Be as Socially Complex as Chimps and Elephants
description: A review of earlier research shows giraffes have the markings of social creatures, including friendships, day care and grandmothers.
content: Giraffes seem above it all. They float over the savanna like two-story ascetics, peering down at the fray from behind those long lashes. For decades, many biologists thought giraffes extended this treatment to their peers as well, with one popular wildlife guide calling them “aloof” and capable of only “the most casual” associations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Idaho Town Is Upended in Search for Missing Boy: ‘We Are All In’
description: Michael Joseph Vaughan, 5, whose family calls him Monkey, was last seen on July 27 near his home in Fruitland, Idaho, according to the boy’s family. The police say they have no leads.
content: For 10 days, the quiet bedroom community of Fruitland, Idaho, has been overrun by drones, canine units and hordes of on-foot volunteers, all scouring the city in a desperate effort to find a 5-year-old boy whose family calls him Monkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geoffrey Wheatcroft
title: America’s Dismal Foreign Policy — and What to Do About It
description: Andrew Bacevich’s “After the Apocalypse” analyzes the role of the United States in the world and concludes major changes are needed.
content: AFTER THE APOCALYPSE America’s Role in a World Transformed
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Pitcher
title: Welcome to ‘Healing Girl Summer’
description: Whether it’s hot, healing or healthy, some singles have been dating differently this summer.
content: Although the summer opened with promises, or threats — depending on your perspective — of a “hot girl summer” and a “hot vax summer,” the surge of the highly contagious Delta variant may have, at least for now, dashed hopes of a hedonistic few months. But there’s another group whose plans weren’t so contingent on the virus disappearing: those who have embarked on a “healing girl summer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Japan Brings Home the Gold Medal in Baseball, a National Passion
description: The sport, absent from the Olympics since 2008, will not be played in the 2024 Paris Games, but is expected to return in Los Angeles in 2028.
content: YOKOHAMA, Japan — After stepping on second base for the final out, Japan shortstop Hayato Sakamoto felt awash with a new sensation. For so long, Japan had never achieved Olympic glory in a beloved sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Stella Zawistowski mixes it up so solvers can sort it out.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — STELLLLLLAAAAAAAAAA!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Here’s what happened in Tokyo on Saturday.
description: TOKYO — The United States men’s basketball team lost to France in the group stages, but beat that team when it counted most, on Saturday in the gold medal game, 87-82. Kevin Durant had 29 points.
content: TOKYO — The United States men’s basketball team lost to France in the group stages, but beat that team when it counted most, on Saturday in the gold medal game, 87-82. Kevin Durant had 29 points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Smarsh
title: What to Do With Our Covid Rage
description: We can start by being honest about our anger and where it comes from.
content: In the spring, I received my Covid-19 vaccination shots from county health workers in an old building on the main street of a tiny Kansas town. My first dose came from a quiet nurse wearing a plastic visor over his N-95 mask and a leather cowboy belt with ornate metal inlays. My second dose came from a smiling older woman who, when I reported with vague concern that I had experienced strong side effects from the first shot, patted me on the shoulder and said, “It’s better than a tube down your throat, hon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: A Memorable Olympics, but for the Right Reasons?
description: A feat of organizational planning and execution in a pandemic left even gold medalists hurrying home from an atmosphere drained of pomp and full of anxiety.
content: TOKYO — The kaleidoscopic stands of Tokyo’s Olympic Stadium — a disordered mosaic of white and green and reddish-brown seats — were designed to evoke the sun-dappled floor of a Japanese forest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: ‘Ka-POW!’
description: Christina Iverson and Jeff Chen manage to cut a puzzle into 1,000 intricate pieces so we can put them all together again.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Christina Iverson and Jeff Chen team up this week for a feat of grid architecture worthy of a nomination for the Pritzker Prize. You’ll see their grid has a sort of loaf-shape of white squares sitting at bottom center, completely walled off from the rest of the puzzle. That’s intentional. Another sign you might be in for an adventure? The instructions at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Paying the Price for Premier League Riches
description: The surplus players at English clubs would make fine assets for teams across Europe. The problem is that the clubs that could use them cannot afford them.
content: The headed clearance did not quite get the requisite power, or direction. It floated, rather than fizzed, out of Brentford’s penalty area, the danger not quite clear. Two Manchester United players converged on it, sensing opportunity. The ball bounced off the turf, not too high, not too quick, and hung in the air for just a second. And that is where Andreas Pereira met it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Japan gets its first baseball gold, a highlight for the host country.
description: Behind a strong pitching effort, Japan shut out the Americans, 2-0, in the gold medal game.
content: YOKOHAMA, Japan — Back after a 13-year absence from the Olympics, the baseball gold medal came down to a showdown between the two biggest baseball countries in the world: the United States and Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Alicia Parlapiano
title: The Kindergarten Exodus
description: As the pandemic took hold, more than 1 million children did not enroll in local schools. Many of them were the most vulnerable: 5-year-olds in low-income neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: The United States closed out its run to win gold — its fourth in a row.
description: The Americans beat France, 87-82, in the gold medal game.
content: SAITAMA, Japan — It was not always pretty, but in the end, the United States men’s basketball team ascended to the heights they were always expected to reach. Overcoming a slow start to the Olympic tournament, the Americans dispatched France, 87-82, with relative comfort in the final game on Saturday morning at Saitama Super Arena to win their 16th gold medal in the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: The Olympic Marathon in Sapporo: A Test of Survival
description: The runners best able to handle the brutal conditions prevailed. Peres Jepchirchir of Kenya won the race, with Brigid Kosgei taking silver and Molly Seidel winning bronze in her third-ever marathon.
content: Peres Jepchirchir, 27, of Kenya won the women’s Olympic marathon in 2 hours 27 minutes 20 seconds on Saturday in Sapporo, Japan, 500 miles north of Tokyo, where officials moved the 26.2-mile race in a preventive but futile attempt to escape the heat and humidity that have smothered the Summer Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: The United States and France battle for the gold medal in men’s basketball.
description: TOKYO — The men’s basketball tournament at the Tokyo Olympics comes to a close on Saturday with the gold medal game between the United States and France in the morning (on NBC; follow our live coverage), and a third-place matchup between Australia and Slovenia later in the day (7 a.m. Eastern on USA).
content: TOKYO — The men’s basketball tournament at the Tokyo Olympics comes to a close on Saturday with the gold medal game between the United States and France in the morning (on NBC; follow our live coverage), and a third-place matchup between Australia and Slovenia later in the day (7 a.m. Eastern on USA).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Welcome to the Kevin Durant and Jayson Tatum show.
description: The Americans lead France, 44-39, at halftime.
content: It goes without saying, but having Kevin Durant on your team is a very nice luxury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Armando Chaguaceda and Coco Fusco
title: Cubans Want Much More Than an End to the U.S. Embargo
description: They should have the right to create a society by and for themselves.
content: In the last month, Cuba has been rocked by the largest antigovernment protests in decades in response to the country’s Covid-19 crisis, food and medicine shortages, a shrinking economy and longstanding restrictions on rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Is a Big Casino Footprint in a Tiny Principality a Good or a Bad Bet?
description: Liechtenstein, where gambling had largely been illegal until 2010, now has more casinos per capita than Macau or Monaco. Some critics worry that it’s more than the principality can handle.
content: VADUZ, Liechtenstein — It was a drab Tuesday evening in an industrial neighborhood in northern Liechtenstein, but that did not deter a steady stream of drivers in cars bearing an array of international plates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Cindy Adams, Gossip’s G.O.A.T.
description: So she’s in a new documentary. So what? The 91-year-old columnist just wants to bust out of her Park Avenue penthouse and hit the town again.
content: When Donald Trump was president, the world should have been Cindy Adams’s oyster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: The U.S. women’s basketball team faces Japan for the gold.
description: TOKYO — The Olympic women’s basketball tournament concludes late Sunday morning (Saturday night in the United States) with a potentially lopsided matchup between the United States and Japan. (Follow live coverage here.)
content: TOKYO — The Olympic women’s basketball tournament concludes late Sunday morning (Saturday night in the United States) with a potentially lopsided matchup between the United States and Japan. (Follow live coverage here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Ashley Nicole Black Is Her Own Competition
description: The comedian was nominated twice in the same Emmy category for her television writing. She’s just getting started.
content: At first, Ashley Nicole Black didn’t get why people kept sending her the meme of Spider-Man pointing at an identical Spider-Man, an image often used to joke about situations in which two incredibly similar people face off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron DePasquale
title: India won its first gold in track and field.
description: Neeraj Chopra won the men’s javelin, giving India its first gold at the Tokyo Games and only its second ever at the Summer Games.
content: India has at last won gold in track and field at the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola and Matt Futterman
title: Sifan Hassan wins her third Olympic medal, this time another gold in the 10,000 meters.
description: Hassan won the bronze in the women’s 1,500 meters, and the gold in the women’s 5,000 meters.
content: TOKYO — At the end of 24,500 meters of hard running in six races over nine days, Sifan Hassan of the Netherlands stood alone before tumbling to the track, disbelief etched across her face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Learning to Love Solitude (and Hate Oatmeal) on a 15,534-Mile Canadian Trek
description: For six years, the filmmaker Dianne Whelan hiked, biked, paddled, snowshoed and skied from the Atlantic to the Pacific and north to the Arctic. Here’s what she learned along the way.
content: In 2015, the independent Canadian filmmaker Dianne Whelan set out on what is now known as the Trans Canada Trail, a nearly 17,000-mile recreational trail that spans green paths, roads and waterways from the Atlantic to the Pacific and north to the Arctic Ocean. On Aug. 1, in the company of her parents, partner and friends, Ms. Whelan, 56, walked the last few feet to become the first person to complete the continuous trail (minus a few spur trails) that links all three oceans by land and water. She plans to produce a documentary, “500 Days in the Wild,” detailing her six-year experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Behind Durant, U.S. Men’s Basketball Finds Path to Olympic Gold
description: The Americans, after struggling at the beginning of the tournament, beat France, 87-82, for their fourth consecutive gold medal.
content: SAITAMA, Japan — Gregg Popovich, the head coach of the United States men’s basketball team, exhaled on Saturday afternoon as he contemplated his team’s 87-82 victory over France to win an Olympic gold medal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Boris Johnson won’t need to quarantine, his office says, despite a positive test on his team.
description: Downing Street pushed back at news reports suggesting the British prime minister should be in isolation after a staff member tested positive during a recent official trip.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain will not have to quarantine even though a member of the team that accompanied him to Scotland this week tested positive for the coronavirus during the trip, his office said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Morse
title: U.S. broadcast highlights on Saturday morning include gold medal games in baseball and soccer.
description: The United States and Japan will play for top honors in baseball, while Brazil and Spain meet for the soccer title. Women’s golf, men’s volleyball and water polo are among other events with gold medals on the line.
content: The next-to-last day of the Tokyo Olympics wraps up on Saturday with the gold medal contest in men’s soccer and additional gold to be awarded in women’s golf, men’s volleyball and beach volleyball, men’s platform diving, women’s water polo and much more. All times are Eastern and are subject to network changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor and Arya Sundaram
title: How Cuomo Took Advantage of #MeToo
description: When a movement swept the world, the New York governor cast himself as its champion. But even as he signed protections and surrounded himself with feminists, he was committing fresh offenses, according to a new report.
content: Two summers ago, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo stared into a camera, signed a bill and made a promise to the women of New York. “Let’s actually change things,” he said, underscoring each word of resolve with a chop of his hands as he approved sweeping new protections against sexual harassment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Robinhood’s Unfinished Business
description: The company’s unresolved legal troubles cast a shadow on its I.P.O. rebound.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan, Jon Huang, Emily Rhyne, Bedel Saget, Joe Ward, Jeremy White and Josh Williams
title: Decisive Moments From the Tokyo Games, Frame by Frame
description: See the Summer Olympics in a series of composite images.
content: See the Summer Olympics in a series of composite images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Harris, Eden Weingart, Ashley Wu, Alice Fang, Nikolas Diamant and Andrew Das
title: Dressel vs. Phelps. McLaughlin vs. Muhammad. Visualizing Olympic Champions, Present vs. Past
description: See how the fastest swimmers and runners from Tokyo 2020 compare with past champions, plus watch visualizations of more than 40 Olympic races.
content: See how the fastest swimmers and runners from Tokyo 2020 compare with past champions, plus watch visualizations of more than 40 Olympic races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: The Most Notable 'Firsts' From the Olympics
description: As the Tokyo Games wind down, we look back on some memorable debuts and victories.
content: As the Tokyo Games wind down, we look back on some memorable debuts and victories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: U.S. Businessman Responds to Sentencing in Russia
description: Michael Calvey, an American businessman working in Russia who had been convicted on embezzlement charges, maintained he was innocent and called the conviction “simply outrageous” after he was given a suspended sentence of five and a half years.
content: Michael Calvey, an American businessman working in Russia who had been convicted on embezzlement charges, maintained he was innocent and called the conviction “simply outrageous” after he was given a suspended sentence of five and a half years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Wildfire Forces Hundreds to Escape Greek Island by Sea
description: The flames tore through the coastline of Evia, a Greek island, causing residents and tourists to evacuate by ferry, as southern Europe grapples with one of its worst heat waves in decades.
content: The flames tore through the coastline of Evia, a Greek island, causing residents and tourists to evacuate by ferry, as southern Europe grapples with one of its worst heat waves in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Where Does the Catholic Church Go From Here?
description: Readers discuss the papacy of Francis and the internal politics of liberals versus traditionalists.
content: To the Editor:
